title: 114_hr470
content: The Act may be cited as the "Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forest Land Adjustment Act of 2015". It includes findings and definitions. The Act, known as the "Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forest Land Adjustment Act of 2015," contains findings stating that certain National Forest System land in Georgia is inefficient to manage or has lost its value for National Forest purposes. The Act authorizes the sale of this land for the public interest, with proceeds used by the Forest Service to purchase land for National Forest purposes in Georgia. The term "Secretary" in the Act refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. The Act also grants land conveyance authority. The Secretary is authorized to sell or exchange United States' rights in National Forest System land in Georgia totaling approximately 3,841 acres. The U.S. Forest Service-Southern Region in Georgia is authorized to sell or exchange approximately 3,841 acres of National Forest System land. The Secretary may modify boundaries based on land management considerations, and the conveyance will be done through a quitclaim deed. Maps of the land will be available for public inspection until sold or exchanged. The Secretary will convey land through a quitclaim deed and may reserve rights for management purposes. Land sold must be at market value as determined by appraisal or competitive bid. Consideration for the sale of land under this Act must be paid in cash, at market value determined by appraisal or competitive bid, and subject to approval by the Secretary. The Secretary may accept a cash equalization payment in excess of 25 percent of the value of any land exchanged. The Secretary has the authority to sell land at public or private sale, including competitive sale by auction, bid, or otherwise, in the best interest of the United States. The Secretary has the authority to make public or private solicitations for the sale or exchange of land, reject inadequate offers, use brokers or third parties for land disposition, and pay commissions from sale proceeds. SEC. 4 of the Act authorizes the Secretary to deposit sale proceeds into the Sisk Act fund for land acquisition in Georgia without further appropriation. Funds cannot be used to acquire land without the owner's written consent.
